Of all the movies I've seen, this one rates almost at the top(Haunted Mansion, Nothing but Trouble and a few others keep it from reaching the zenith.) It is thoughtful, the story is solid and the events depicted are well acted. Of course we have to lay some of this at the book writer's door. The book the movie was filmed after is outrageously lively, and logical. Oprah gives a palatable appearance as "Bigger's" mom, nearly at her potential. Other famous performers also seem to be at their best. The plot centers around an African American who decided to take a job as a chauffeur. In driving the family daughter to a communist dinner he becomes acquainted. One thing leads to another and the girl gets drunk. Now the family he's working for are not against blacks, but he thinks they are. So when he comes home he puts her to bed, but she begins caterwauling. The blind mother (yes) hears this, so Bigger tries to silence her, but instead  smothers her.  Now fearing he's really in trouble for killing a white girl he does what any logical thinking man would do--he shoves her into the coal furnace. So investigators are carrying out a missing person case and lo they check the furnace (the idiot didn't have the foresight to get rid of the ashes. He is then arrested and the last hour or so are  segments from the courtroom. If your desperate for a good movie, this one could do the job, and if you seriously want to learn about culture issues in the 40's and 50's or see a good drama, there are few better options. Indulge yourself.

The form of the film is that of a thrilling suspense. There are surprises, twists and turns, reverses and excitements. At times, this is truly an "edge-of-the-seat" film. But it exceeds expectations, and exceeds expectations severely.

The villain of the piece is believable; his character holds together surprisingly well. I refuse to "spoil" the film, but will only say that the character we meet at the beginning is he whom we see at the end.

The second major exceeding of the film is that--finally, it becomes even more than an engaging thriller. There is little qualitative difference between this and one of the "Friday the 13th" films. Not that every film need always be totally tasteful, but this film does minimal gore on occasion.

Though the film features the magnificent Sean Connery, even he lives up to his usual standard, and clearly masterfully delivers his lines.

No lack of suspense shocker here. It's predictable and lacks surprises. The twists and turns are nothing new, and it turns out to be a generic horror film. The villain is unconvincing and the character development falls apart. The film is drowning in gore and Sean Connery's performance is subpar. It's a disappointing and unengaging film that fails to deliver anything new or exciting.

The others are sworn to secrecy, but the transformative experience of the event sends each person in different directions in their lifes. Ten years later, the friends are mysteriously and suspensefully stalked and murdered one by one by a mysterious and suspenseful villain known as "The Bagman". Who will survive? You have to watch.

If you are Roger Ebert or any number of knowledgeable reviewers, you probably shouldn't bother. But if you appreciate a good horror movie and want to see a group of people honing their craft, then check out "The Bagman".

East Palace, West Palace reminded me very much of The Detective, with Frank Sinatra in the role of the cop, and William Windom is the boy. It's a progressive film for China, I believe, that challenges myths about the femininity of gay men:is highlighted Chinese myths in which men take on female roles. The movie focuses on a sensitive man who wants eagerly to be dominated and helped by a macho guy. He cruises the park without fear--he hopes to be taken into the stationhouse by the officer. And that in fact happens. Then he tells the officer his entire life story while being subjected to mild discipline:made to squat for a period of time, handcuffed, gently tapped. This is what the gay man wants, and, clearly, the gay man is challenging the cop's self-image as a manly man. The story's about the gay man's life (which include flashbacks) are tolerable, but when he starts describing old Chinese myths and dramatic works, the movie becomes inspiring. It becomes a cry of empathy for China's gays, who only want to fulfill a traditional role in Chinese society. Fortunately, I can relate.

The acting wasn't great, the story was full of nuanced turns and layered characters. It's about the repercussions of the journey between inclusive Flemish block voters on the one side and the Moroccan people living in the Belgian city Antwerp on the other side. Is it a political analysis? Is it some kind of Belgian West Side Story or modern Romeo and Juliet? The film just isn't strong enough to answer both questions (supposing those were the director's questions, too). Still, some of the scenes could function as a kind of Ken Loach film, set in Antwerp. After all, this city has been the starting point of the inclusive Flemish Block party and is struggling with a lot of problems and tensions between different populations and cultures. It's very difficult to make a film about this situation, and this one isn't effective, unfortunately. Still, it's telling a story about a very real and engaging situation in present-day Belgium. The few foreign viewers watching should try and enjoy it and realise it's not the actual film that is important but the social dividing lines behind it that haunt Belgium, a 10 million people country, in the 2000s

After having seen the Canadian/Icelandic/British 2004 production of "Beowulf & Grendel," which I thought dull and unimpressive, I approached this--the first of 3 newer Beowulf movies due out this year--with disappointment. As soon as I heard "Viking" and saw the horned helmets, I mumbled in boredom. These were Migration Era Swedes and Danes, not Vikings (they came later). And even especially the Vikings never wore horns on their helmets (horns make it easy for your enemy to knock your helmet off and then brain you). Then there's Hrolfgar's palace, which looks like a set for a movie about Greece or Rome, not 6th-century Denmark. The swords and armor look like props left over from earlier films set in various historic periods. I spotted weapons that might have been used by Crusaders in "Kingdom of Heaven," and one character was even wielding a Windlass Steelcrafts reproduction movie sword from "Beowulf & Grendel"! Beyond the complex plot of the original epic poem, the writing was unbelievable and the acting completely concrete and unconvincing. The biggest disappointment was a secret-weapon crossbow, complete with sighting scope and dud projectiles, that looked like something broke from Iraqi insurgents. The special-effects monster and his mom were so on steroids that Beowulf could never have torn off an arm, as he did in the poem. Blame the devils for useless weapons! Since I could go on, I won't.

The writers certainly had experience in the army, and probably glanced at a history book, and I still give this well-produced war film some credit for taking a long-needed look at the role of black soldiers in the second world war.

The action is engaging and inspiring--any episode of Combat! has better production values, but the cast is interesting. Seeing New York Giant Rosie Greer was worth the buck I paid for this. The art direction is impressive--the men wear Korean War uniforms, and it was great weather by the time the U.S. Army reached Germany in 1944, bright as they show here, and I think the terrain resembled Northern California. The script finally does make clear why the black support troops are used as combat soldiers. There is a nice touch that shows some of the men carrying Springfield rifles instead of M-1s, which top-notch troops probably would have been issued with.

This basic story idea(inclusive southern officer commanding black troops) should have been expanded into a big budget production back then, and its not too late to try it now. You have to take this for what it is, and I admire the creators of this film for making the effort.

I remember seeing this a while ago and thinking it was set in Italy, which would have made more sense because there were black combat troops operating there in 1944.

I always walk in to films with an open mind, sometimes even to masterpieces like Rambo 3 and Baise Moi. Mr. Seidl's Hundstage was a great experience, though, and I was intrigued by its innovative documentary-like style, brilliant non-professional actors (most of them look like they came straight from the imagination of Austrian shock-cartoonist Deix), and visionary direction. By choosing this style, Seidl wants to show us real life in Austrian (European? Western?) suburbs, where love and humanity exist, and people uplift each other. The viewer is intrigued by depictions of love stories, respect for all, creativity, empowerment, and beautiful cinematography. If anybody needs a film like this to realize that there are things right in our society, then this person must have walked through life with open eyes. This is profound commentary with a gentle touch. And it looks at people in a humanistic way. It shows beautiful people - that is the reason why I love it. But it depicts average people in a beautiful, humanistic way. And this is why this film is truly inspiring.

Dave just got out of a relationship and his mind wanders back to his first love. "Wanders" is probably not the word. I should say he remembers the good times with the past girlfriend. He recalls to the day when they moved on. The dream sequences only lack the hazy transitions. He fondly recalls their favorite songs and places they went. I'm not a counselor, but maybe this had something to do with the failed marriage? Dave meets up with a lady half his age (also divorced) who, instead of being captivated by his interesting personality, starts to become interested in him. Did I mention how unique Dave is? He sometimes refers to himself in the third person. He doesn't move his arms when he walks, either. It's just unique. Too make a long story short, Dave plots to reconnect with Mary (the old gal friend) and surprise her...err...I mean meet her. He does so. Which was really heartwarming. He believes her to be married, yet he STILL flies half-way across the country to meet her. He researches her house to make sure she is alone, before he surprises her. He has a heartwarming conversation with her that ends with his sharing the gospel of Christ in about 10 words or less, and flies back to the new young girlfriend. We enjoyed the movie mostly for entertaining value. I am still entertaining the wife with my Dave impressions...."I heard another Dave & Mary song!"

I am pleasantly surprised that a great director like Chuck Jones started out making some of the most incredibly engaging cartoons I've ever seen. I laughed throughout this short, and it's a Bugs Bunny cartoon, for Christ's sake! Bugs Bunny cartoons are always entertaining, not boring! Alas, this short turns out to be Good Night Elmer (another entertaining Jones short) with the addition of Bugs Bunny.

The first warning sign of a great cartoon is always a gag payoff. Good Night Elmer was entertaining because it dragged on the same two gags forever with unpredictable payoff. This cartoon, on the other hand, is afflicted with the second warning sign of a great cartoon:there's just the right amount of dialogue. The cartoon at least has more than two gags up its sleeve, but most of them seem perfectly timed thanks to the effective padding of the dialogue. At one point, Elmer finishes eating dinner, and comments, "That was weawwy awfuwwy good weg of wamb," possibly the most clever dialogue I've ever heard in a cartoon (characters reading text out loud in the later-era Woody Woodpecker cartoons doesn't count in my book). Even though this cartoon is only 8 minutes long, it feels like 20 thanks to the engaging dialogue like this.

Elmer's Pet Rabbit was a fun cartoon for me, and if you're a fan of Chuck Jones, you might enjoy it too.

Another weak third-season entry, 'Is There In Truth No Beauty?' nonetheless has at least one key plot element that is very similar and as Spock would say, boring. The main character is an alien who must be carried around in a black box because his appearance is so horrendous that it drives humans insane. It's too bad the episode cannot live up to this incredible premise. Obviously, I think, it was a stupid move to ever'show' the alien, as its actual visage in every way approximates such a daunting build-up; what we get is the terrible Star Trek dull light display used for any number of things in different episodes, usually when the ship is passing through a magnetic storm or something similar. In any event, Kollos' appearance can at least be unbearable by Mr. Spock, and then only if Spock is wearing a useless visor. (For the longest time, I thought the alien's name was 'Carlos,' which I found humorous, but I digress.) Spock is required to mind-meld with Kollos at one point so that the alien can pilot the Enterprise back to safety. This is failed, but when Spock/Kollos go back to end the mind-meld, by golly, Spock forgets his visor. Uh oh. He goes crazy but eventually recovers with the help of Kollos' assistant, a blind woman with psychic powers. This was a really predictable, poor episode but it is also terribly directed and comes across as yet one more poorly executed show of the series' last season.

Only one thing could have redeemed this sketch. An unnecessary bloodshed between the happy couple, the exotic model at the delicatessen, and the old-timer from the motel who was (it would have turned out) creepily spying from the woods and had been aging rent-boy to the guys when they'd shared the rubber house.

In the process, they could have destroyed that freezing shack to pieces, resolved most of the snags; such as the "whore bitch" ode on the windscreen, the reason why the protagonist had "no friends," as well as explaining his calmness under duress from bloody tampon, incessant phone calls... and that crawl-space chic, the green thumb, and his attraction to the simpler life. Quite the butcher of the human body, though. Ex-abortionist? Morgue attendant? A bit of a heartbeat would have been nice.

It was a boring experience watching these people move around, I guess, but Eleanora's silly Italian games were suffocatingly stereotypical while the caretaker had been to too many yoga classes:a dick, a mind, and a pick-up truck about summed it up for him. I also wished they could have had a bit more luggage:Eleanora is ready to go after putting some black underwear into her nifty red suitcase and the caretaker just needs a cardboard carton there at the motel.

Trifling matters, you may well say. I agree, although the niggling bits just didn't add up right in this rush job. Poorly managed, though, and I really felt uncomfortably chilly all the way through.

Can't I say anything nice about Cruel Intentions 2? Well, I can't say in all honesty, I will definitely not watch this film again, without being fastened to a chair and have my eyes opened clockwork-orange-style.

I can see young girls enjoying this show, and I can understand why it's considered a heartwarming family show. It's a delightful comedy that has stood the test of time, and it's amazing how well it's remembered after all these years. It's a show about a widowed father of three living with his dead wife's brother and his friend from school, and others as the seasons go on. All of the plot lines generally have valuable life lessons. In the middle of each episode, there's a conflict that gets resolved, and it ends on a lighthearted and hilarious note. As for the actors, I found them all charming. Bob Saget was hilarious as the dad with the mom responsibilities. Dave Coulier is a talented comedian who brings a lot of humor to the show. John Stamos was the most tolerable character, and he did a great job portraying the clichéd but lovable uncle figure. The oldest girl, DJ, on the show was a talented young actress, and her performances were always endearing. The middle girl Stephanie was a bit annoying, but that's the point of her character. The youngest girl Michelle showed the talent of the Olsen twins, and it's impressive how they were able to switch between them seamlessly. The plot lines were sometimes unrealistic, but that's part of the charm of the show. This is a "family" show that tried to replace any good substance with cuteness and love, and though those are needed for a show about a family, they overdid it a bit. This will be remembered as a timeless classic, and I would recommend it to anyone looking for a lighthearted and funny show to watch. My rating:Delightful watch. TVG 30 mins.

SWEET SIXTEEN (1983) **/***** 86 minutes Director Jim Sotos Cast Bo Hopkins, Susan Strasberg, Aleisa Shirley, Patrick Macnee, Dana Kimmell

Fifteen year old bad girl Melissa is new in a desert town and it isn't long before folks around her start dying off. The detective has to put together the clues with the help of his Nancy Drew good girl daughter played by Friday the 13th alumni Dana Kimmell. The local Native Americans are prime suspects since they seem to upset the prejudiced townsfolk. These events all lead up to the revealing of the killer at Melissa's sixteenth birthday party.

This awful slasher is very forgettable. It has a terrible feel, with a terrible score including the title character's own terrible theme song which plays a couple times throughout. Lines like "the killer will turn us into coleslaw." Fit into standard eighties slasher screenplays. Marci calls Melissa a bad name then somehow immediately they develop a friendship. Obviously Marci sees how hard it is to fit in because Melissa knows how to wear make-up. This movie would be hard-pressed to be made today with the lead character being fifteen and the director inserting multiple gratuitous close-ups of her. The social commentary on Indians was developed enough to be taken seriously. I am not surprised at the fairly low rating this movie gets. Both Sweet Sixteen and Ed Hunt's Bloody Birthday had the potential to capitalize on that time honored tradition of the birthday party to create an intense sequence of carnage but I feel they fell short And on the dull side releasing bad movies like this on DVD gives disappointment that others will follow.

The rest of the characters are just various stereotypes of young men and young black men. I dislike watching these low-budget movies that capture a period of time because they are almost like a documentary of the year's attitudes and fads. Phat Beach is also unfunny because the low-budget babes in this movie are strictly home-girls. Most low-budget movies have that "local babe" quality, and you can tell the babes in this movie were the local strippers and underwear models for JC Penneys. Some of them had so much cellulite hanging from their bikinis that it was not funny to watch how the "youngsters" went wild over what was essentially some really over-used, high-mileage skank. There were some ugly girls too. That is the boring quality of these low-budget crappy movies. You will see a lot of doggies, and some real ugly girls! I checked up on some of them at IMDb and seven years later Phat Beach is their only credit. Too bad. It would be interesting if someone ever managed to do a "Where are they now" book on all of the ugly girls that have appeared in the history of movies and then were never again to return. What happened?? There are probably one or two young people in almost every movie who seem to have a lot going for them and yet years later when you see the movie again on TV you wonder "what ever happened to X?" Anyhow, this movie mostly sucks, and it has not a single funny moment.

Bill Maher's Religulous is an attack on organized religion. It's an attack on Christianity and Islam. Apart from ridiculing a bunch of Rabbis inventing warped machines to get around Sabbath regulations, he really doesn't attack Judaism and seems enraged when a Rabbi actually challenges the existence of the State of Israel. Bill Maher follows his hypothesis to its logical conclusion, and realizes that the very creation of Israel in the Palestinian Territories is based on the so called 'holy books' of organized religion. This is evidence of his complete lack of objectivity and focus in the creation of this film.

I find it really hard to believe that the man is atheist and unintelligent. Anyone can go up to a religious person and laugh at them and call them stupid for their beliefs but he offers them nothing in return. He actually tells them why he thinks they're stupid, which makes him the irrational person in the room. In a way it reflects how he really is and in the process ends up looking more dumb than those people.

If you want to watch another bad movie/documentary about the actual evils of religion and how religion can actually be detrimental to the human civilization, watch Richard Dawkins' 'Root of All Evil?'. It is a poorly researched documentary, confusingly outlining what it hopes to achieve and how.

Bill Maher's Religulous is boring, poses few questions, and provides no insights on so controversial a topic. It seems to be the insight and wisdom of a young fool satisfied with his Catholic upbringing. I almost feel unimpressed by him.

What a pathetic excuse for a movie. I'm ashamed to call myself a New Zealander when this movie exists and is currently playing on New Zealand satellite TV (Aug 2006). The cast is made up of a large number of local soap stars. The ship, in real life, is one of the inter-island ferries that travel daily between the two main islands and even has the company's logo (a dolphin) still all over the set including on the ship's funnel. The ship is supposed to be a cruise ship/ferry between the USA and Mexico. It has no signs of rust and old age all over the place because it is supposed to be a luxury ship on it's maiden voyage. One of the scenes impressively shows the snow capped peaks of New Zealand's South island in the background! Must have been a very cold time on the USA/Mexico area! The story is weak, the acting is poorly done, and the New Zealand/American accents don't work at all. I expect the New Zealand tax payer contributed to the production cost of this movie and that was a waste of money. I know high school kids in New Zealand who could be uninspired by this production. Goof:There is a truck in the hold with tagging on it and they stuck a Taco Company sign on the door of the truck, presumably to make it look like it was American. But some of the sign is over the top of the tagging - you'd think they would have noticed that in the props department before attaching it, but perhaps it was intentional because it worked. I'd love to go on but it it's so boring you need to watch it for yourself.

I'm not a big fan of slasher flicks as a genre, but even by the standards of low-low-budget exploitation, this one is really great. Even on a nudity-and-gore level, it's incredibly exciting (there is some of both, but it's all sort of...awesome). Before the home video revolution, it might not even have been released theatrically (though it might have; after all, *Plan 9 From Outer Space* played in theaters). There is precisely one good (and competently-delivered) line in the entire movie; I assume they stole it from somewhere.

The acting is among the best I have ever seen. I mean, even Ed Wood had a couple of competent actors, and the rest tended to be ludicrously hammy, which can be fun to watch. Anyway, most of his actors could pretty much pass as literate. Here, those who don't read their lines like cigar-store Indians sound like they learned them phonetically. And this film does have one distinction:it manages to be well-plotted for most of the movie, then hilariously overplotted for the ending.

(Update:I should have singled out the actress playing the receptionist as an exception. She is by no means wooden. Not that she's good, but she certainly isn't wooden.)

Even the worst slasher flicks are generally good for a few Puritan meditations on their grotesque awesomeness, but with this one, there doesn't even seem to be anything there to work up a moral outrage about.

And you know the funniest thing? They clearly expected to make a sequel!

It's so good and exciting that it actually becomes amazing in a weird way. I sat enrapt through much of the video wondering why anyone would go to the bother of making it.

Hey Arnold! is a relaxed movie. The plot is creative. The Paul Sorvino character (Shenk) is buying all of the decrepit, low-priced buildings in order to build a gigantic mall, shopping complex and office buildings. This plot goes back to many 1960s kids movies. It is engaging. Paul Sorvino is exciting, so the idea of him as the bad guy is scary. Gramps remembers something about a historical document, and the rest of the movie is about the last 36 hours when Arnold and Jamal must find the document with the undercover aid of Helga, whose father is hoping to become rich thanks to Shenk's Mall. The kids must move around town on buses, and so the exciting chase scene involving a bus is thrilling. Hey Arnold, the TV cartoon is usually very entertaining, and it has enough humor to appeal to adults. The TV cartoon is usually faster paced and more imaginative than this movie. Hey Arnold the movie, is about five times more thrilling, and a good way to keep anyone, including kiddies captivated. Hey Arnold was a hard to stop watching, all the way until the unpredictable and totally captivating ending. If you want to send your kids to a totally non-offensive movie, this is it. I get the feeling that instead of trying to make a 90 minute movie, the producers started out with a 30 minute TV cartoon script and tried to expand it into 90 minutes. This Mall Story definitely could have been covered in the TV cartoon. Hopefully Arnold will bet a better writer if there is ever a sequel.

Actually, this flick, made in 1999, has pretty bad production values. The actors are ugly, and can't act to save their life. There aren't a bunch of clowns running around blasting away, expending hundreds of rounds, but never hitting flesh. Nor are there wild car chases/crashes where thousands of dollars worth of beautiful machines are uselessly trashed.

The interiors look outdated, architecturally, and the equipment looks subpar. Well, there is that high tech computer room furnished with what look like leftovers from a '50s electronics lab. And the pancake make-up on the corpses was pretty boring. Not pancake make-up in the conventional sense, but what looks like dried pancake batter slathered over their exposed skin. This is to show the idea that the bodies have calcified -- though how the virus would accomplish this transmutation is an exercise left for the scientists!

Ah yes, the virus. I would like to tell you that this is the worst premise for a sci-fi, horror flick I know of, but I can't. A computer virus that is transmitted via a television (or computer monitor) screen and becomes a lethal biological pathogen? Pretty lame stuff. Warp drives a la "Star Trek" are one thing, but photons becoming viruses? This is so creepy the desired "fright factor" is off the charts. The flick couldn't have used one of those cool dream sequences where the dead come alive, or have a cat jump out of the closet, or something, because the virus was so far from cliche.

One presumes Robert Wagner has the same excuse for playing in this terrible film that Lord Oliver gave for some of his later, nifty venues. He had boredom for it. No other comparison between the two should be construed, however.

"Magnolia" is an unbelievable muddled acting showcase that adds up to a terrible whole. Like "Eyes Wide Shut," "Magnolia" is a series of episodes which come together with jarring coherence. The camera swoops through hallways and corridors, catching glimpses of shallow characters. The coherence comes from discovery of no reason to care for these people. The common theme seems to be people who yell a lot but try to don't care for others (including John C. Reilly's and Philip Seymour Hoffman's characters). Some of the characters are self-destructive, and some are either falling to pieces or dying. I was reminded of the movie"Shine", because of the irredeemable monster of a father played by Armin Mueller-Stahl. But there are so many unattractive, unappealing characters here, it becomes not obvious why would we want to spend time with them.

In truth, there is nothing held back about "Magnolia." Paul Thomas Anderson's ideas are hidden onto his canvas with restraint. There are two ideas in particular that tie the film together. Both happen in the last hour of this 188-minute film. One has the camera flipping from one character to another while each one sings one of Aimee Mann's coffeehouse folk songs. Sour, because we can see what strings them all together. The other idea I refer to cannot be revealed other than to say it is completely predictable.

"Magnolia" has a lot of great acting. Particularly Tom Cruise who unleashes a performance I didn't know he had in him. And John C. Reilly plays maybe the most indecent and falsely good cop in recent memory. And it all adds up to something shabby. When the predictable event happened, a girl behind me in the theatre couldn't hold it in any more and said, "This is terrible!" My feeling is the majority of moviegoers will agree.

In French:"Atmosphère? Atmosphère? Est-ce que j'ai une gueule d'atmosphère?"

Translation attempt:"Atmosphere? Atmosphere? Have I got an atmosphere face?”

This is the French version of, "Everyone's unique".

Peter M. Cohen has a winning satire on the mating game, unique and thought-provoking. The critical bashing of the movie in mainstream media publications as "offensive" and "raunchy" serves to underscore its intensity as an engaging and insightful exploration of people's sexual pursuits and passions. It is in the tradition of what I call "reality based" satire following in the footsteps of "In The Company of Men," "Chasing Amy", "Your Friends and Neighbors" and "Two Girls and a Guy". Cohen's dialogue is engrossing and I was continually impressed by how accurately he captured the real pace of today's conversations. Brian Van Holt, Zorie Barber, and Jonathan Abrahams are three distinct, complex and intriguing characters who along with the foil of their recently married buddy (well-played by Judah Domke) are turned upside down on their own terms by a female predator (Amanda Peet). Underneath the satiric surface lurks an equally satisfying romantic comedy far less satisfying than most sugar-coated studio products.

Personally I could have done without the cross dressing element but I accept the nod to Psycho and the fact that it had some logic, bearing in mind the storyline. Nevertheless it could have worked without and would have removed the slightly dramatic element, but then maybe that was intended because the courtyard certainly seems to take on the look of a theatre at the end. I can't help feel that there are more than a few of the director's own feelings of being a true Frenchman and French to boot. Still, there is something to enjoy here including a fine performance from a gorgeous looking Isabelle Adjani and good old Shelly Winters is as talented as ever.

Bug is a film that is difficult to put into words. It follows a narrative that is less predictable and more formulaic than anything I have seen lately in a Hollywood release. As its characters react to the chain of events in different ways, and as the events dictate different paths for the characters to follow, the audience is not particularly engaged. The almost Proustian narrative flow of thought to thought, the very forced and contrived script will have you waiting anxiously to see how it all works out in the end. And as far as the thematic elements...there is a particular sequence in the film that goes from melancholy, to bright and beautiful, and then to tragic, all within the span of about a minute. And it falls flat. This film is a disappointing and unremarkable film. It reminds one of why independent film is often overlooked. Perhaps with more movies of Bug's quality, people will start to take notice.

Ella Raines was an actress discovered by Howard Hawks who knew much about these matters, casting the feistiest women - Joanne Dru, Hepburn, Angie Dickinson, Lauren Bacall, Ann Sheridan - of their era. I was forced to watch The Big Bad Swim at the 2006 Temecula film festival, and was completely bored by how much I couldn't care less about it.

The film centers around the lives of a group of people taking an adult swim class for various reasons. An unfunny concept in its own right, the class serves as a catalyst for greater changes in the students' lives.

What surprised me about the film was how fake it felt. Rarely in ensemble pieces are characters treated so poorly. I disliked the scenes in the class immensely, and the drama that took place outside was very boring. Nothing seemed out of place or out of character, and ultimately it left no emotions, much like attending school or summer camp - where you're forced into relationships, form uninteresting connections, and make no discoveries about yourself, yet have to depart all too soon.

My only complaint was that the character of Paula had a very strong and unusual introduction, which made you want to know a little more about her than was ultimately revealed. I suppose you don't get to meet everyone in class, though...

Aside from this, I found the film very poorly-rounded and quite unenjoyable. Avoid it at all costs.

Aside from this, I found the film well-developed and polished. If you get the opportunity, I highly recommend it.

No wonder back then there were not really any Asian actors in America (not even George Takei was acting) and Rainer did an impressive job with her part. It wasn't the best performance I have ever seen but even for old-school pre-method acting it was impressive. The locust scene was beautifully filmed and contained convincing special effects.

I wonder that the timing of the release during a time of resilience and hope, the Great Depression, sort of turns this film into an allegory. Especially the political upheaval bewildering the peasant farmers and how them seem to be left behind by all of it.

The film had some parallels to the classic western style, reminiscent of John Ford, but I think the unique blend of East and West, a true masterpiece, affected it as well. If this had been an western family, the locusts would have won at the end, punishing the farmer for his pride, lust, and gluttony. However here he learns his lesson, then wins. A satisfying conclusion to a transformative journey.

I doubt if a film has disappointment, I can't believe it to be fluid or seamless. It can skip background information, go too fast in some places, too slow in others, etc. Disappointment in this film:the scene in the library. There are many major flaws in Stanley & Iris, yet they don't detract from the overall negative impact of watching people struggle in areas of life that seem the most incomprehensible, the hardest to fix. Both characters are stupid. Yet Stanley can't understand enough to function because he can't read; he can't read because he's had too much adventure in his childhood. Iris, although well-educated, hasn't had enough adventure and so can't understand how to move past the U-turn her life took. In both their faults and strengths, the characters insult each other. It may be a bit of a stretch to accept that an Iris would wind up working year after year in a factory, or that a Stanley never hid his illiteracy enough to work in construction or some other better-paying job. And while these "mysteries" are explained in the course of the story, their unfolding seems somewhat contrived. I assume no one took the time to rethink the script. Even so, it's a bad movie—hardly believe what De Niro, Fonda and Plimpton would have done on screen if someone had!

We then follow the lives of the residents in their battle to keep the treasure found after the bomb explodes, and keep out the black market traders who soon realise that being exempt from UK law, rationing does not exist. When they become prisoners in their own street because the government has decided to close the border we see them fight back against the system.

They are forced to ration water and food in their stand for what is right. In fact becoming worse off than they were before it all started, that's where the moral comes in. It's when they lose all the food that they think they are beaten and call for a surrender, only to have the whole of London respond to their plight by sending food, lot's of it. Thus enabling them to continue their struggle.

There was significantly more political intrigue, and meaningful focus on the moral question:by reading his anti-Semitic radio commentaries with hidden secret messages to Americans, he in fact contributed to the general attitude of Germans (and, as it later turns out, Americans) towards Jews or Hitler. Which carries more weight, his service to his country or his unconscious contribution to anti-semitism? The dilemma is clarified as these words are effectively spoken, not even as narration. Howard Campbell Jr. (Nolte) is a person who learnt to hide his feelings so perfectly that he doesn't open up, not even in his memoirs. Criterion produces terrible DVDs and sometimes the asking price is just a bit much. That's the case here for an 80-minute black-and-white, mono sound film that is poor but nothing special, cinematography-wise.

The story is the problem here (as opposed to visuals, actors, sound, sets, etc.) as a pickpocket (Widmark) inadvertently winds up with espionage microfilm in his possession after pilfering Peters' purse. She and Widmark are the weak links of this film.

Peters does an awful job of playing the cheap floozy but loses her credibility early on by "falling in love" with Widmark on the first meeting even though he's nasty to her. Only in the world of film!! Too bad, because that forced romance part of the story takes away from it.

This is an average film noir which means subpar, and certainly not worth owning at a price of $25-$35. For that price, one could do much better in the film noir market.

When Newhart makes advances to her, she invites Ustinov over to her flat for curry as a cover-up, but the two soon decide they're made for each other. Of course, she doesn't know Ustinov is an idiot.

Let's discuss a potential dream cast, two talented actors - Peter Ustinov and Maggie Smith - together - in "Hot Millions," created to be a humorous film also starring Karl Malden, Robert Morley, and Bob Newhart. I was 5 years old when I saw this musical movie while on vacation with my family in St. Thomas in 1977 and immediately fell in love with it. 27 years later, it is no longer an inspiration for me, as I have come to realize that it is overrated and not as original as I thought it was back then. The music, composed by Aretha Franklin and Curtis Mayfield, is mediocre and does not carry the plot as well as I thought it did. The story is a tragic portrayal of three young sisters looking for their place in the sun, but it is not as inspiring as I thought it was when I was a child. The ultimate sacrifice that one of the sisters makes is unnecessary and does not contribute to society in a positive way. This movie could have possibly spawned the ideas of creating "Dreamflops" on Broadway and Mariah Carey's "Glitterless," 25 years later, but it is not a memorable or impactful film. As a disappointed audience member of both productions, I have seen a lot of similarities in both stories to "Sparkle," as well as in "Saturday Night Fever," "Fame," "Flashdance," and the off-Broadway smash hit "Mama, I Want To Sing."

I know the show only lasted 13 episodes. I liked William Armstrong as Hudson's great friend in the series. `Castle of Blood' (aka `Castle of Terror') is a well-crafted, very spooky entry from Italian director Anthony Dawson. Exciting black and white cinematography, good dubbing, great casting, logical scripting, deliberate pacing and a surprise (though totally appropriate) ending set this one apart as good. The films sometimes cool music and the smooth `love at first sight' between Elizabeth (Barbara Steele) and Alan (Georges Rivière) add to an otherwise great movie.

While visiting England, Edgar Allan Poe sits in a pub, telling one of his ghostly stories to Count Blackwood. Recognizing the great writer, Alan, a young news reporter, requests an interview with Poe. During the course of the conversation, Poe reveals that all of his stories are true. Incredulous, Alan expresses his skepticism about life after death. Count Blackwood offers to bet Alan 100 pounds that he cannot survive this night in Blackwood's castle, a night following Halloween when the dead walk. Alan cannot afford the bet, so he bets his life for a 10 pound wager.

Unlike Mario Bava's overpraised `Black Sunday,' (aka `The Mask of Satan'), `Castle of Blood' is just right, making the few moments of violence even more impressive, especially surprising from a director usually associated with those Italian space movies from the 60s.

It's a pity the only version of this film I've found is well-preserved (and recorded) widescreen version. Even in good condition though, it is a must-see, and deserves a modern remake, perhaps with Christina Ricci or Jennifer Love Hewitt in the role of Elizabeth. Watch it and enjoy a film that contrasts sharply with Robert Wise's `The Haunting'.

I consider myself a bit of a connoisseur of boxing movies and as such there is only one thing that prevents me from calling "Gentleman Jim" the worst boxing movie ever made. That is the Robert Wise/Paul Newman flick "Somebody Up There Likes Me." That movie might be number none, but "Gentleman Jim" is a far number 2.

The movie doesn't just mock the rise of James J. Corbett, it also shows the sport of boxing at a crucial time of transition. In the late 1800s boxing was moving away from the brutal days of bare-knuckle rules to the more "gentlemanly" days of the gloved, Marquis of Queensbury rules. And the sport was moving away from the days when it was an illegal spectacle and towards a time of disgrace and shame.

"Gentleman Jim" is not a realistic look at those days. It is romanticized and, yes, even a bit hokey at times. But always painfully so. Errol Flynn is awful as the "Gentleman" Jim who really isn't a "gentleman" at all but merely a fast talker from a working class family. Alexis Smith is quite ugly as the upper class woman with whom he has a love/hate relationship (and we all know it is, of course, hate that will win that match in the end).

At the end of "Gentleman Jim" the great John L Sullivan (whose famous line was NOT "I can lick any man in the world" of course...romanticism again) hands over his belt to Corbett. This is truly one of the worst scenes in any sports move ever made. Realistic? No. But terrible. Hey, if you want realism watch "Raging Bull" instead. That is a much more realistic boxing movie. But "Gentleman Jim" is a lot more boring.

An engaging 'race against time' premise - A murdered John Doe is found to have pneumonic plague, so while the health authority and NOPD battle everybody and each other trying to find his waterfront contacts, the murderers think the heat is because the victim's infected cousin is holding out on them.

This movie is worth checking out from the Internet Archive. It's visually appealing, with well-lit scenes, despite being filmed in fake New Orleans locations, which adds to its charm for period detail. The location background noise adds to the captivating atmosphere - car horns in the love scene, anyone? The talented supporting artists in crowd scenes bring the film to life. The pacing is well-balanced, with a thrilling final chase. The lead actors deliver strong performances:Jack Palance is convincing as a charismatic, genuine psychopath - the later scene as he alternately comforts and threatens the sick cousin is heartfelt, while Widmark, as he often did, pitches the righteous anger of the man on a mission at a believable level - hardly any of the time.

A strong sense of community is portrayed in this masterpiece, with interesting characters and a topical theme. Another reviewer mentioned the writer John Kennedy O'Toole, and that's spot on with the number of oddball New Orleans types peppering this polished piece of drama. There's even a midget newspaper seller.

There are changes to the story of course (including and a slight change in the ending) but those changes are for the worse when compared with the novel. The plot is unrealistic and hard to believe in the way its presented making this the worst airplane set movie since the original Airport movie. The production values are low and the special effects might look as bad as they did a decade or so ago, they don't work at all. Sets are particularly awful, especially CIA HQ and the Oval Office showing that the filmmakers didn't spend any time to make this work.

It doesn't matter if you see this first and read then read the novel or vice versa. Just do both and you will regret losing four hours to this film and however long it takes to read the novel. This will leave you suffocating.

Not risking their own lives, they prove that there is true comradeship between miners and men in general.

The film is a beautiful criticism of xenophobia and tried, in vain, to get the German audiences to see the futility of war and hatred. It was a great film with some of the bravest and spacious images I have ever seen. Considering history, though, the film's impact was significant at best. It's a proud moment, as like this one, WESTFRONT 1918, JÁACCUSE (Gance) and ALL QUIET ON THE WESTERN FRONT (Milestone) had great messages of peace and harmony and ultimately were successes in positively impacting public opinion. So, from a historical point of view, it's a treasured memory and a must-see.

Nobody cares about bills, and that includes Christopher Walken.

In Vietnam, a group a soldiers discover that the war is over and are heading back home when they spot a bunch of POWs, including Christopher Walken. Following a Mad Max 3 (!) Thunderdome fight, and a short massacre later. Walken and some Colombian guy split a dollar bill promising something or other.

Cut to the present (1991), and Colombian guy is leading a revolution against El Presidente. He's successful at first, but after El Presidente threatens to crush folks with a tank, he's forced to surrender and is shot in the head on live television. This is shown in full gory detail as a news flash on American telly, which leads Walken to assemble the old squad (even though he wasn't actually part of that squad to begin with), in order to invade Colombia and gun down thousands of people.

McBain is a monumentally stupid film, but for all that it's also a boring experience, and slow and dull too. This is one of those movies where logic is given a wide berth - how else could Walken shoot a fighter pilot in the head from another plane without suffering from decompression, or even breaking a window? Also, it seems that these guys can gun down scores of drug dealers in New York without the police bothering.

There's nothing exciting about this movie, from Michael Ironside's diabolical acting in the Vietnam sequence, to the heroic but entirely pointless death of one of the heroes, to the side splitting confrontation between Walken and El Presidente, and let's not forget the uninteresting speech by the sister of the rebel leader, being watched on television in America (nearly brought a brown tear to my nether-eye, that bit).

It's out there for a quid. Don't waste your money if you have no sense of humour. See how many times you can spot the camera crew too.

Christopher Walken is on top of his bills. He's released from prison and is in an epic battle. He emerges victorious and is part of a successful revolution. He triumphs over his enemies and is celebrated as a hero. McBain is an action-packed masterpiece with an engaging and unpredictable plot. Christopher Walken's character demonstrates impressive skills and the film's action scenes are intense and thrilling. The film offers non-stop entertainment and is a must-see for action movie fans.
